bio:
**Sir Andrew Barron Murray**  [OBE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Officer_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire "Officer of the Order of the British Empire")  (born 15 May 1987) is a British professional  [tennis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis "Tennis")  player from Scotland. Murray represents  [Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain_Davis_Cup_team "Great Britain Davis Cup team")  in his sporting activities and is a three-time  [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)")  tournament winner, two-time  [Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympics "Olympics")  champion,  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup")  champion, winner of the  [2016 ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles"), and former  [world No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players").

Murray defeated  [Novak Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic")  in the  [2012 US Open final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 US Open – Men's Singles"), becoming the first British player since 1977, and the first British man since 1936, to win a  [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)")  singles tournament. Murray is also the first British man to win multiple  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon")  singles titles since  [Fred Perry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Perry "Fred Perry")  in 1936,[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Newbery-12)  winning the tournament in  [2013](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2013 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles")  and  [2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles").

Murray is the men's singles  [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's singles")  and  [2016 Olympic gold medallist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles"), making him the only tennis player, male or female, to have won two Olympic singles titles. He featured in  [Great Britain's Davis Cup-winning team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain_Davis_Cup_team "Great Britain Davis Cup team")  in  [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2015 Davis Cup World Group"), going 11–0 in his matches (8 singles and 3 doubles) as they secured their first  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup")  title since  [1936](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1936_Davis_Cup "1936 Davis Cup").[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Newbery-12)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-13)


## Early and personal life

Andy Murray was born in Glasgow, Scotland, the son of  [Judy Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judy_Murray "Judy Murray")  (née Erskine) and William Murray.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-birth1-4)  His maternal grandfather,  [Roy Erskine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Erskine "Roy Erskine"), was a professional  [footballer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_football "Association football")  in the late 1950s.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-14)  Murray is a supporter of  [Hibernian Football Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hibernian_F.C. "Hibernian F.C."), one of the teams his grandfather represented,[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-15)  and  [Arsenal Football Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C.").[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-16)

Murray began playing tennis at the age of three when his mother Judy took him to play on the local courts.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-17)  He played in his first competitive tournament at age five and by the time he was eight he was competing with adults in the Central District Tennis League.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-18)  Murray's elder brother,  [Jamie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Murray "Jamie Murray"), is also a professional tennis player, playing on the doubles circuit, and became a multiple Grand Slam winner in the discipline (both men's and mixed).[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-19)[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-20)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-21)[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-22)[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-23)

Murray grew up in  [Dunblane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane "Dunblane")  and attended  [Dunblane Primary School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_Primary_School "Dunblane Primary School"). He and his brother were present during the 1996  [Dunblane school massacre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_school_massacre "Dunblane school massacre"),[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Faultless_young_Scot-24)  when Thomas Hamilton killed 16 children and a teacher before shooting himself; Murray took cover in a classroom.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-25)  Murray says he was too young to understand what was happening and is reluctant to talk about it in interviews, but in his autobiography  _Hitting Back_  he states that he attended a youth group run by Hamilton and his mother gave Hamilton lifts in her car.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-26)  Murray later attended  [Dunblane High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_High_School "Dunblane High School").[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-times_interview-27)[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-guardian_interview-28)

Murray's parents split up when he was 10, with the boys living with their father while being mentored in tennis by their mother.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Murray_facts-29)  He believes the impact this had on him could be the reason behind his competitive spirit.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-30)  At 15, he was asked to train with  [Rangers Football Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangers_F.C. "Rangers F.C.")  at their School of Excellence, but declined, opting to focus on his tennis career instead.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-31)  He then decided to move to Barcelona, Spain. There he studied at the  [Schiller International School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schiller_International_School "Schiller International School")  and trained on the clay courts of the Sánchez-Casal Academy, coached by Pato Alvarez.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Coaches-32)  Murray described this time as "a big sacrifice".[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-guardian_interview-28)  His parents had to find £40,000 to pay for his 18-month stay there.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Murray_facts-29)  In Spain, he trained with  [Emilio Sánchez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilio_S%C3%A1nchez "Emilio Sánchez"), former world No. 1 doubles player.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-guardian_interview-28)

Murray was born with a bipartite  [patella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patella "Patella"), where the kneecap remains as two separate bones instead of fusing together in early childhood, but was not diagnosed until the age of 16. He has been seen holding his knee due to the pain caused by the condition and has pulled out of events because of it.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-33)

In February 2013, Murray bought  [Cromlix House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cromlix_House "Cromlix House")  hotel near Dunblane, where his brother Jamie had celebrated his wedding in 2010[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-34)  but which had since ceased trading, for £1.8 million; the venue re-opened as a 15-room five-star hotel in April 2014.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-35)  Later that month Murray was awarded freedom of Stirling and received an Honorary Doctorate from the  [University of Stirling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Stirling "University of Stirling")  in recognition of his services to tennis.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-36)

Murray began dating Kim Sears, daughter of player-turned-coach  [Nigel Sears](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigel_Sears "Nigel Sears"), in 2005.[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-37)[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbcengage-38)  Their engagement was announced in November 2014,[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbcengage-38)  and they married on 11 April 2015 at  [Dunblane Cathedral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunblane_Cathedral "Dunblane Cathedral")  in his home town,[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbcwedding-39)  with the reception at his Cromlix House hotel. The couple live in  [Oxshott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxshott "Oxshott"),  [Surrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrey "Surrey")[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Andy_Murray_vows_he_will_never_be_a_%E2%80%98tax_exile%E2%80%99-1)  with their son and two daughters.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-40)[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-41)[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-42)  He identifies himself as a  [feminist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feminist "Feminist"), and has been repeatedly vocal in his support for women players and coaches.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-43)[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Murray_Feminist-44)

Murray has invested in up to 30 UK businesses using  [Seedrs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seedrs "Seedrs"), a crowdfunding platform.[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-45)

## Career

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Andy-Murray-Singles-Ranking-History-Chart.png/220px-Andy-Murray-Singles-Ranking-History-Chart.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy-Murray-Singles-Ranking-History-Chart.png)

Andy Murray Singles Ranking History Chart

### Junior tennis

[Leon Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leon_Smith_(tennis_coach) "Leon Smith (tennis coach)"), Murray's tennis coach from 11 to 17,[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Coaches-32)  described Murray as "unbelievably competitive", while Murray attributes his abilities to the motivation gained from losing to his older brother Jamie. In 1999, at the age of 12, Murray won his age group at the  [Orange Bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junior_Orange_Bowl_(tennis) "Junior Orange Bowl (tennis)"), a prestigious event for junior players.[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-46)  He won it again at the age of 14, and is one of only nine tennis players to win the Junior Orange Bowl championship twice in its 70-year history, alongside the likes of  [Jimmy Connors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Connors "Jimmy Connors"),  [Jennifer Capriati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jennifer_Capriati "Jennifer Capriati"),  [Monica Seles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monica_Seles "Monica Seles"), and  [Yishai Oliel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yishai_Oliel "Yishai Oliel").[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-ynetnews.com-47)

In July 2003, Murray started out on the  [Challenger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Challenger_Tour "ATP Challenger Tour")  and  [Futures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITF_Men%27s_Circuit "ITF Men's Circuit")  circuit. In his first tournament, he reached the  [quarter-finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarter-finals "Quarter-finals")  of the  [Manchester Challenger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manchester_Open "Manchester Open").[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-48)  In September, Murray won his first senior title by taking the  [Glasgow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glasgow "Glasgow")  Futures event.[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-49)  He also reached the semi-finals of the  [Edinburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh")  Futures event.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-50)

For the first six months of 2004, Murray had a knee injury and couldn't play.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Injury_2004-2005-51)

In July 2004, Murray played a Challenger event in  [Nottingham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nottingham "Nottingham"), where he lost to future  [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)")  finalist  [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga")  in the second round.[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-52)  Murray then went on to win Futures events in  [Xàtiva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X%C3%A0tiva "Xàtiva")[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-53)  and  [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rome "Rome").[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-54)

In September 2004, he won the  [Junior US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis) "2004 US Open (tennis)")  and was selected for the  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup")  [World Group play-off match against Austria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Davis_Cup_World_Group_Play-offs "2004 Davis Cup World Group Play-offs")  later that month;[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-55)  however, he was not selected to play. Later that year, he won  [BBC Young Sports Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year_Young_Personality "BBC Sports Personality of the Year Young Personality").[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-56)

As a junior, Murray reached as high as No. 6 in the world in 2003 (and No. 8 in doubles). In the 2004-instated combined rankings, he reached No. 2 in the world.[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-57)

Junior Slam results:  Australian Open: -  
French Open: SF ([2005](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_Singles "2005 French Open – Boys' Singles"))  
Wimbledon: 3R ([2004](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_Singles "2004 Wimbledon Championships – Boys' Singles"))  
US Open:  **W**  ([2004](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_Singles "2004 US Open – Boys' Singles"))

### 2005: Turning professional

Murray began 2005 ranked No. 407,[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-58)  but when he was in South America in January, he hurt his back and had to take three months off.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Injury_2004-2005-51)

In March, he became the youngest Briton to play in the  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup").[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Youngest-59)  Murray turned professional in April and was given a  [wild card](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wild_card_(sports)#Professional_tennis "Wild card (sports)")  entry to a clay-court tournament in Barcelona, the  [Open SEAT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_SEAT "Open SEAT"), where he lost in three sets to  [Jan Hernych](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jan_Hernych "Jan Hernych").[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-60)  In April, Murray parted acrimoniously from his coach Pato Alvarez, complaining about his negative attitude.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Mark_Petchey-61)  Murray then reached the semi-finals of the boys' French Open, where he lost in straight sets to  [Marin Čilić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87 "Marin Čilić").[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-62)

[Mark Petchey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Petchey "Mark Petchey")  agreed to coach Murray for four weeks until the end of Wimbledon, but it metamorphosed into a full-time position.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Mark_Petchey-61)  Given a wild card to  [Queen's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club_Championships "Queen's Club Championships"),[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-63)  Murray progressed past  [Santiago Ventura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santiago_Ventura_Bertomeu "Santiago Ventura Bertomeu")  in straight sets for his first ATP match win.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-64)  Following a second-round win against  [Taylor Dent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Dent "Taylor Dent"),[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-65)  he played former Australian Open champion  [Thomas Johansson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Johansson "Thomas Johansson")  in the third round, losing in three sets after cramping and twisting his ankle.[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-66)[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-67)  Following his performance at Queen's, Murray received a wild card for  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon"). Ranked No. 312, Murray became the first Scot in the  [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era")  to reach the third round of the men's singles tournament at Wimbledon.[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-68)  In the third round, Murray lost to 2002 Wimbledon finalist  [David Nalbandian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Nalbandian "David Nalbandian")  due to cramping and fatigue, having led two sets to love.[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-69)

Following Wimbledon, Murray won Challenger events on the hard courts of  [Aptos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aptos "Aptos")  and  [Binghamton, New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binghamton,_New_York "Binghamton, New York"). He then experienced his first  [Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Masters_1000 "ATP World Tour Masters 1000")  event at  [Cincinnati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters "Cincinnati Masters"), where he beat  [Taylor Dent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Dent "Taylor Dent"), before losing in three sets to then-No. 4,  [Marat Safin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marat_Safin "Marat Safin"). With a wild card entry, Murray played  [Andrei Pavel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrei_Pavel "Andrei Pavel")  in the opening round of the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)"), where he recovered from down two sets to one to win his first five-set match.[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-70)  However, he lost in the second round to  [Arnaud Clément](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnaud_Cl%C3%A9ment "Arnaud Clément")  in another five-set contest.[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-71)  Murray was again selected for the Davis Cup match against Switzerland. He was picked for the opening singles rubbers, losing in straight sets to  [Stanislas Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanislas_Wawrinka "Stanislas Wawrinka").[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-72)  Murray made his first ATP final at the  [Thailand Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PTT_Thailand_Open_(ATP) "PTT Thailand Open (ATP)")  where he faced No. 1  [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer"). Murray lost in straight sets.[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-73)

Murray beat  [Tim Henman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Henman "Tim Henman")  in their first meeting, at the  [Basel Swiss Indoors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2005_Davidoff_Swiss_Indoors_%E2%80%93_Singles#Top_Half "2005 Davidoff Swiss Indoors – Singles")  in the first round, and eventually reached the quarter-finals.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-74)

In November, Murray captained Scotland at the inaugural  [Aberdeen Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aberdeen_Cup "Aberdeen Cup")  against England led by  [Greg Rusedski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Rusedski "Greg Rusedski").[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-75)  This was an exhibition tournament and the only event where Murray played Rusedski, they never met on the Tour. Rusedski beat Murray in the first match, but Murray won the second. This was also the first time that Andy and his brother  [Jamie Murray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Murray "Jamie Murray")  played doubles as seniors.[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-BBC_format-76)  Scotland defeated England 4½ – 2½.[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-77)  He completed the year ranked No. 64 and was named the 2005  [BBC Scotland Sports Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Scotland_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year "BBC Scotland Sports Personality of the Year").[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-78)

### 2006: First ATP Title and British No. 1
The 2006 season saw Murray compete on the full circuit for the first time and split with his coach Mark Petchey[[79]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-79)  and team up with  [Brad Gilbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Gilbert "Brad Gilbert").[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-80)

On 27 February, Murray became the British No. 1, ending  [Tim Henman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Henman "Tim Henman")'s seven-year run. Murray was now world No. 42,  [Greg Rusedski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Rusedski "Greg Rusedski")  No. 43, and Tim Henman No. 49.[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-81)  Rusedski regained his British No. 1 status on 15 May[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-82)  for eight weeks.[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-83)

Murray suffered a straight sets defeat at the Australian Open, to Argentine  [Juan Ignacio Chela](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Ignacio_Chela "Juan Ignacio Chela")  in the first round[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-84)  and to  [Gaël Monfils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils "Gaël Monfils")  at the French Open, in five sets.[[85]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-85)  Murray did reach the fourth round for the first time at both Wimbledon (beating 3rd seed Andy Roddick in the 3rd round) and the US Open.[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-86)[[87]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-87)

Murray played in Davis Cup ties against  [Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"),  [Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel "Israel")  and  [Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine"). Murray missed the opening singles matches before losing the doubles as Britain lost their tie against Serbia.[[88]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-88)  During the tie with Israel, Murray won his rubber and lost the doubles before pulling out with a neck injury before the reverse singles, as Britain lost the tie.[[89]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-89)[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-90)[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-91)  Against Ukraine, Murray won both his singles rubbers, but lost the doubles, as Britain won the tie.[[92]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-92)[[93]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-93)[[94]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-94)

At the Masters, Murray lost in the first round in Miami,[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-95)  Monte Carlo and Rome.[[96]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-96)[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-97)  Murray went out of the tournaments in Indian Wells and Hamburg in the second round.[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-98)[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-99)  Murray reached his first Masters semi-final in  [Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto "Toronto")  at the  [Rogers Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogers_Cup_(tennis) "Rogers Cup (tennis)"), losing to  [Richard Gasquet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Gasquet "Richard Gasquet").[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-100)

At  [Cincinnati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_%26_Southern_Financial_Group_Masters "Western & Southern Financial Group Masters"), Murray became only one of two players, alongside  [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal"), to defeat Roger Federer in 2006, breaking the Swiss star's 55 match winning streak on hard courts.[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-101)  He lost two rounds later to Andy Roddick, but broke into the top 20 for the first time.[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-102)[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-103)  In the final two Masters events in Madrid and Paris, Murray exited both tournaments at the last-16 stage ending his season, with losses to  [Novak Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic")  and  [Dominik Hrbatý](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominik_Hrbat%C3%BD "Dominik Hrbatý").[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-104)[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-105)  When the tour reached  [San Jose, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Jose,_California "San Jose, California"); In November, the  [Aberdeen Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aberdeen_Cup "Aberdeen Cup")  was held for the second time, with Murray leading team Scotland and  [Greg Rusedski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Rusedski "Greg Rusedski")  captaining England.[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-111)  Scotland won 6½–1.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-112)

### 2007: Ascending to the top 10
Murray reached the fourth round of the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles#Section_8 "2007 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), where he lost a five-set match against No. 2, Rafael Nadal.[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-113)

Following the  [Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Sony_Ericsson_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2007 Sony Ericsson Open – Men's Singles"), where he reached the semi-finals,[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-114)  Murray reached the No. 10 ranking on 16 April.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Singles_ranking-115)

The British No. 1 sustained tendon damage during his first round match at the  [German Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Qatar_Telecom_German_Open "2007 Qatar Telecom German Open")  in Hamburg. Murray was up 5–1 when he hit a forehand from the back of the court and snapped the tendons in his wrist, leaving him out of action from 15 May until 7 August, thereby missing Wimbledon.[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2007_wrist_injury-116)  During this rest period, Murray rose to No. 8, but by 7 August, he had dropped to No. 14.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Singles_ranking-115)

Murray suffered a third round loss at the  [US Open.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles#Section_3 "2007 US Open – Men's Singles")  At the Masters tournaments, Murray reached the semi-finals of Indian Wells and Miami. At Rome and Cincinnati, Murray exited in the first round whilst going out in the second in Canada. In the final two masters tournaments, Murray exited in the third round in Madrid and he went out in the quarter-finals of Paris. Murray won titles in San Jose and St. Petersburg.[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-117)  He also reached the final of tournaments in Doha and Metz, finishing the season ranked 11th in the world.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Singles_ranking-115)

In November, Murray split with his coach Brad Gilbert and added a team of experts along with  [Miles Maclagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Maclagan "Miles Maclagan"), his main coach.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-118)[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-119)

### 2008: First major final and Masters titles

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Andy_Murray_at_the_2008_US_Open3.jpg/220px-Andy_Murray_at_the_2008_US_Open3.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy_Murray_at_the_2008_US_Open3.jpg)

Murray at the 2008 US Open

In 2008, Murray suffered a first round loss at the Australian Open to eventual runner-up Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, and a third round loss at the French Open to  [Nicolás Almagro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Almagro "Nicolás Almagro").[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-120)  Murray then made his first Grand Slam quarter-final at Wimbledon before making his first final at the US Open. During the tournament in New York, Murray claimed his first win over Nadal. That victory meant that he'd become the first player from Britain since Greg Rusedski in 1997 to reach a major final.[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-121)  In his first Grand Slam final Murray suffered a straight sets loss to Federer.[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-autogenerated2-122)[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-123)  At the  [Beijing Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics "2008 Summer Olympics"), Murray suffered one of the worst defeats of his career, losing his first round singles match to No. 77  [Yen-hsun Lu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yen-hsun_Lu "Yen-hsun Lu")  of Taiwan in straight sets. That abject defeat was still on his mind in a BBC interview five years later – despite an intervening Olympic gold medal and a head-to-head win – when he met the same player (now ranked No. 75) in the second round of Wimbledon 2013.[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-124)

In the Masters tournaments Murray went out in round four in Indian Wells and the first round of Miami. In the clay Masters Murray made the third round of Monte Carlo and Hamburg and the second of Rome. On the American hard court swing Murray made the semi-finals of Toronto before winning his first Masters shield in Cincinnati. He added another shield to his collection in Madrid;[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-125)  before losing in the quarter-finals of Paris. Now at No. 4 in the world, Murray qualified for the first time for the  [Masters Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals "ATP World Tour Finals"). He played well in defeating an injured Federer[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-126)  but lost to Davydenko in the semi-finals.[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-127)  Murray ended 2008 ranked No. 4. Murray also won tournaments in Doha, Marseille and St Petersburg.

### 2009: Ascent to world No. 2, two Masters titles

Murray opened the 2009 season with a successful defence of his title at the  [Qatar Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Qatar_ExxonMobil_Open "2009 Qatar ExxonMobil Open")  in  [Doha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doha "Doha"), defeating Andy Roddick in straight sets.[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-128)  At the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2009 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), Murray made it to the fourth round, losing to  [Fernando Verdasco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernando_Verdasco "Fernando Verdasco").[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-129)  Murray won his eleventh career title in  [Rotterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament "2009 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament"), defeating No. 1, Nadal in three sets.[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-130)  Murray next went to Dubai but withdrew before the quarter-finals with a re-occurrence of a virus that had affected him at the Australian Open.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-131)  The virus caused Murray to miss a  [Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup")  tie in Glasgow. Murray then lost in the finals to Nadal at  [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Indian_Wells_Masters "2009 Indian Wells Masters"),[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-132)  but won a week later in Miami over Djokovic for another masters title.

Murray made the quarter-finals of the  [2009 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_French_Open "2009 French Open")

In the lead-up to the French Open, Murray beat No. 9,  [Nikolay Davydenko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolay_Davydenko "Nikolay Davydenko")  at the  [Monte Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles#Finals "2009 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles"), the first time he had beaten a top ten player on clay,[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Davydenko-133)  though he lost to Nadal in the semi-finals. Murray was upset in round two of the  [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2009 Internazionali BNL d'Italia – Men's Singles")  by qualifier  [Juan Mónaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_M%C3%B3naco "Juan Mónaco"), and he reached the quarter-finals of the  [Madrid Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open "2009 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open"), losing to  [Juan Martín del Potro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Mart%C3%ADn_del_Potro "Juan Martín del Potro"). During this time Murray achieved the highest ever ranking of a British male in the  [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era "Open Era")  when he reached the No. 3 ranking on 11 May 2009.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-tennis1-134)  Murray reached the quarter-finals of the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles#Finals "2009 French Open – Men's Singles"), but was defeated by  [Fernando González](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernando_Gonz%C3%A1lez "Fernando González")  in four sets.

Murray won a title for the first time on  [grass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawn_Tennis "Lawn Tennis")  at  [Queen's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_AEGON_Championships "2009 AEGON Championships")  and became the first British winner of the tournament since 1938. Murray returned to action in  [Montreal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Rogers_Cup "2008 Rogers Cup"), defeating del Potro in three sets to take the title.[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-137)  After this victory, he overtook Nadal in the rankings and held the number two position until the start of the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)").[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-atpworldtour-138)  Murray followed the Masters win playing at the  [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters "Cincinnati Masters"), where he lost to Federer. At the US Open, Murray was hampered by a wrist injury and suffered a straight-sets loss to Čilić.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Wrist_injury_US_Open_2009-139)  Murray won both his singles matches, and lost at doubles in the Davis Cup against Poland,[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-140)  but then missed six weeks with a wrist injury.[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Valencia_2009-141)

In November, Murray won at  [Valencia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Valencia_Open_500 "2009 Valencia Open 500"),[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Valencia_2009-141)[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-142)  but bowed out in round two of the Paris Masters. To end the season, Murray did not make it out of the round robin at the  [World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2009 ATP World Tour Finals")  in London.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-143)  He ended the year ranked #4 for the second consecutive year.
