### 2012: Olympic Gold, US Open champion and Wimbledon runner-up

Main article:  [2012 Andy Murray tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Andy_Murray_tennis_season "2012 Andy Murray tennis season")

With  [Ivan Lendl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Lendl "Ivan Lendl")  as his new full-time coach,[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-182)  Murray began the season by playing in the  [2012 Brisbane International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Brisbane_International "2012 Brisbane International"). He overcame a slow start in his first two matches to win his 22nd title by beating  [Alexandr Dolgopolov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandr_Dolgopolov "Alexandr Dolgopolov")  in the final.[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-183)  In doubles, he lost in the quarter-finals against second seeds  [Jürgen Melzer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Melzer "Jürgen Melzer")  and  [Philipp Petzschner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philipp_Petzschner "Philipp Petzschner")  in a tight match.[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-184)  After an exhibition tournament,[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-185)  Murray made it to the semi-finals of the  [2012 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), where he was defeated by Djokovic in a four-hour-and 50-minute match.[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-186)

At the  [Dubai Duty Free Tennis Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dubai_Tennis_Championships "Dubai Tennis Championships"), Murray defeated Djokovic in the semi-finals, but lost in the final to Roger Federer.[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-187)  After an early defeat at the  [BNP Paribas Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BNP_Paribas_Open "BNP Paribas Open"), Murray made the final of the  [Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Masters "Miami Masters"), losing to Djokovic.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2012ATP-188)  Murray then had quarter-final losses at the Monte Carlo Masters and Barcelona Open, and a third round loss at the  [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Internazionali BNL d'Italia – Men's Singles").[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-189)[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-190)[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-191)  Murray battled back spasms throughout the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 French Open – Men's Singles"), and in the quarter-finals, he was beaten by David Ferrer.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-192)

Murray lost in the opening round of the  [Queen's Club Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club_Championships "Queen's Club Championships")  to No. 65  [Nicolas Mahut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolas_Mahut "Nicolas Mahut").[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-193)  At  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles"), Murray set the then record for the latest finish at the championships when he completed a four-set victory over Marcos Baghdatis at 23:02 BST, which was eclipsed by the 2018 Wimbledon men's singles semi-finals which saw play being completed at 23:03 BST.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-autogenerated1-194)  Murray beat  [Jo-Wilfried Tsonga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo-Wilfried_Tsonga "Jo-Wilfried Tsonga")  in the semi-final in four sets to become the first male British player to reach the final of Wimbledon since  [Bunny Austin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunny_Austin "Bunny Austin")  in 1938.[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-195)  In the final, he faced Federer, but after taking the first set, he lost the match in four sets.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-196)

Murray returned to Wimbledon within weeks, this time to compete in the  [London 2012 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics")  in singles, doubles, and mixed doubles. He partnered his brother Jamie Murray in doubles and suffered a first-round exit to  [Austria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austria_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Austria at the 2012 Summer Olympics")  (Jürgen Melzer and  [Alexander Peya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Peya "Alexander Peya")) in three sets.[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-197)  In the mixed doubles, Murray was partnered by  [Laura Robson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Robson "Laura Robson"). They made it all the way to the finals where they lost to the  [Belarusian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belarus_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Belarus at the 2012 Summer Olympics")  top seeds ([Victoria Azarenka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_Azarenka "Victoria Azarenka")  and Max Mirnyi) in three sets, settling for the silver medal. In singles, Murray lost only one set on his way to the finals where he met Federer, defeating him in straight sets, for the loss of just 7 games.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2012ATP-188)  By winning the Olympic gold medal, Murray became the first British man to win the Olympic singles gold medal in tennis since  [Josiah Ritchie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josiah_Ritchie "Josiah Ritchie")  in 1908, and only the 7th man in the open era to win two medals at the same Olympic Games.[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-198)  Murray retired early in the  [Rogers Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Rogers_Cup_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Rogers Cup – Men's Singles")  due to a knee injury, and was beaten by unseeded  [Jérémy Chardy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%A9my_Chardy "Jérémy Chardy")  at the  [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2012 Western & Southern Open – Men's Singles")  in straight sets.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Andy_Murray_2012_%28cropped%29_2.jpg/220px-Andy_Murray_2012_%28cropped%29_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy_Murray_2012_(cropped)_2.jpg)

Murray at the  [2012 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis) "2012 US Open (tennis)")  where he won his first major title

He next competed in the final major of the season at the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis) "2012 US Open (tennis)"). He cruised through his opening two rounds in straight sets against  [Alex Bogomolov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Bogomolov "Alex Bogomolov")  and  [Ivan Dodig](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Dodig "Ivan Dodig"), before facing a tough four-set battle with  [Feliciano López](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feliciano_L%C3%B3pez "Feliciano López"), where Murray had to win three tie-breakers. In the fourth round, he defeated the Canadian  [Milos Raonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milos_Raonic "Milos Raonic")  in straight sets, and then in the quarter-finals, had to come from a set and two breaks down against Marin Čilić to prevail in four. In the semi-finals, he defeated Tomáš Berdych in a long-fought match that lasted almost four hours, to reach his second consecutive Grand Slam final. Murray defeated Djokovic in five sets, becoming the first British man to win a Grand Slam final since Fred Perry in 1936,[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-199)  and the first Scottish-born player to win a Grand Slam final since  [Harold Mahony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Mahony "Harold Mahony")  in 1896.[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-200)  The win would also set several records for Murray: it involved the longest tiebreak in US Open final history at 12–10 in the first set, it made Murray the first man ever to win an Olympic gold medal and the US Open in the same year, and it tied with the  [1988 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "1988 US Open – Men's Singles")  final (in which Murray's coach Lendl competed) as the  [longest final in the tournament's history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longest_tennis_match_records#Men_4 "Longest tennis match records").[[201]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-201)  By defeating Djokovic in the  [final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles_final "2012 US Open – Men's singles final"), Murray achieved his 100th Grand Slam match win of his career. The victory made Murray part of the "[Big Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis) "Big Four (tennis)")" according to many pundits and contemporaries, including Novak Djokovic.[[202]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-202)[[203]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-203)

In his first tournament after the US Open, Murray reached the semi-finals of the  [Rakuten Japan Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Singles "2012 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships – Singles")  after entering as defending champion. He was beaten by Milos Raonic in a close three-set match. He was defending champion in the  [doubles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Doubles "2012 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships – Doubles")  with his brother Jamie. However, they were knocked out in the quarter-finals by top seeds  [Leander Paes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leander_Paes "Leander Paes")  and  [Radek Štěpánek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radek_%C5%A0t%C4%9Bp%C3%A1nek "Radek Štěpánek"). At the penultimate Masters 1000 tournament of the year in Shanghai, after receiving a bye into round two, Murray's first match was due to be played against  [Florian Mayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florian_Mayer "Florian Mayer"). However, Mayer had to pull out due to injury, giving Murray a walkover into round three. After beating Alexandr Dolgopolov in the third round, he then overcame Radek Štěpánek in a three-set quarter-final. Murray next faced Roger Federer in the semi-finals, whom he defeated in straight sets to set up a second consecutive final against Djokovic, and his third consecutive Shanghai final. After failing to capitalise on five match points, Murray eventually lost in three sets, bringing to an end his 12–0 winning streak at the competition.[[204]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-204)[[205]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-205)  When Nadal pulled out of both the Paris Masters and the Year-End Championships,[[206]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-206)  Murray finished the year at No. 3, after four years at No. 4. This was the first time Murray had finished the year higher than No. 4. At the  _[BBC Sports Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year "BBC Sports Personality of the Year")_  Murray found himself voted third overall, ahead of  [Mo Farah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mo_Farah "Mo Farah").[[207]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-207)  Murray won the World Breakthrough of the Year at the Laureus World Sports Awards.[[208]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-208)

Murray was appointed  [Officer of the Order of the British Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Officer_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire "Officer of the Order of the British Empire")  (OBE) in the  [2013 New Year Honours](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_New_Year_Honours "2013 New Year Honours")  for services to tennis.[[209]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Honours2013-209)[[210]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-210)[[211]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-211)

### 2013: Wimbledon champion and back surgery

Main article:  [2013 Andy Murray tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Andy_Murray_tennis_season "2013 Andy Murray tennis season")

Murray began his 2013 season by retaining his  [Brisbane International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Brisbane_International_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2013 Brisbane International – Men's Singles")  title, defeating  [Grigor Dimitrov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigor_Dimitrov "Grigor Dimitrov")  in the final in straight sets.[[212]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2013_Brisbane-212)  Trying to win his second major in a row, he began the  [2013 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2013 Australian Open – Men's Singles")  well with a straight sets victory over Dutchman Robin Haase. He followed this up with straight set victories over  [João Sousa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Sousa "João Sousa"), practice partner  [Ričardas Berankis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ri%C4%8Dardas_Berankis "Ričardas Berankis")  and French No. 14 seed  [Gilles Simon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilles_Simon "Gilles Simon"). In the quarter-finals he cruised past Jérémy Chardy in straight sets to set up a semi-final clash with Roger Federer. After exchanging sets, Murray eventually prevailed in 5 sets, recording his first Grand Slam tournament triumph over Federer. With this victory, each member of the ATP's most  [dominant quartet of the previous four years (Federer, Nadal, Djokovic and Murray)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis) "Big Four (tennis)")  had beaten the other three at the majors.[[213]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-213)  This victory set up Murray's third consecutive major final appearance, and second in a row against Djokovic. After taking the first set in a tiebreak, Murray was eventually defeated in four sets.[[214]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-214)  His defeat in this final meant that Murray became only the second man in the Open Era to achieve three runner-up finishes at the Australian Open, the other being  [Stefan Edberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefan_Edberg "Stefan Edberg").

At the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Murray lost at the quarter-final stage to Juan Martín del Potro in three sets.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-2013_Indian_Wells-215)  At the  [Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Sony_Open_Tennis "2013 Sony Open Tennis"), Murray made it through his first four matches without dropping a set, and after overcoming Richard Gasquet in the semi-finals, faced David Ferrer in the final. After losing the first set, and facing match point in the decider at 5–6, Murray eventually took the match in a third-set tiebreaker to win his second Miami Masters title, and leapfrog Roger Federer into second place in the rankings, ending a near-decade long time period in which either Federer or Rafael Nadal were ranked in the top two.[[216]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-216)  Murray briefly fell back to No. 3, following a third round defeat by Stanislas Wawrinka in  [Monte-Carlo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "2013 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters"), but reclaimed the No. 2 ranking as a result of Federer failing to defend his title at the  [Mutua Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Mutua_Madrid_Open "2013 Mutua Madrid Open"). Later, Murray lost at the quarter-final stage to Tomáš Berdych in straight sets.[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-217)

At the  [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Open_(tennis) "Italian Open (tennis)"), Murray retired due to a hip injury during his second round match against  [Marcel Granollers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcel_Granollers "Marcel Granollers")  on his 26th birthday. Murray had just battled back to tie the match at one set all after winning the second set on a tiebreak. This left Murray with only eleven days to be fit for the start of the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_French_Open "2013 French Open").[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-218)

Speaking at a press conference after the match, Murray said, "As it is, I'd be very surprised if I was playing in Paris. I need to make a plan as to what I do. I'll chat with the guys tonight and make a plan for the next few days then make a decision on Paris after the next five days."[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-219)  He would go on to withdraw from Roland Garros later, citing a back injury.[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-220)  After a four-week break due to injury, Murray made his comeback at the  [2013 Aegon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Aegon_Championships "2013 Aegon Championships"), where he was the top seed. After a rain delayed first day, Murray had to complete his second round match against Nicolas Mahut, and his subsequent match against  [Marinko Matosevic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marinko_Matosevic "Marinko Matosevic")  on the same day, both of which he won in straight sets. After beating  [Benjamin Becker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benjamin_Becker "Benjamin Becker")  in the quarter-finals, Murray next faced his first top ten opponent since losing to Tomáš Berdych in Madrid, taking on Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the semi-finals. After dropping the first set against the Frenchman, Murray eventually raised his level and won in three to set up a final against Marin Čilić of Croatia, his third consecutive final on grass courts. He came from behind again to beat Čilić in three sets to claim his third title at  [Queen's Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club_Championships "Queen's Club Championships").[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-221)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/AndyMurrayWimbledonTrophyCropped.jpg/170px-AndyMurrayWimbledonTrophyCropped.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:AndyMurrayWimbledonTrophyCropped.jpg)

Murray holds the Wimbledon trophy following his victory in the  [2013 men's final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles_final "2013 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles final")

Going into Wimbledon, Murray had not lost a match on grass since the previous year's final, and was on a winning streak of 11 matches on grass. In the first two rounds, Murray faced Benjamin Becker[[222]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-222)  and Yen-hsun Lu[[223]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-223)  respectively, defeating both in straight sets. His third round match was against 32nd seed  [Tommy Robredo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tommy_Robredo "Tommy Robredo"), and despite a tour comeback over the past year, Murray overcame the Spaniard in straight sets to set up a clash with  [Mikhail Youzhny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mikhail_Youzhny "Mikhail Youzhny"), the highest seed left in Murray's half following the unexpectedly early exits of Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-224)  Despite facing a fightback in the second set, Murray won in straight sets to make it through to his tenth consecutive Grand Slam quarter-final,[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-225)  in which he was to play Fernando Verdasco, the first left-handed player Murray had faced since the  [2012 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis) "2012 US Open (tennis)"). For the seventh time in his career, Murray had to come back from a deficit of two sets to ultimately come through in five,[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-226)  setting up a semi-final clash with 24th seed  [Jerzy Janowicz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerzy_Janowicz "Jerzy Janowicz"), the Polish player who beat Murray in their previous encounter. After Murray failed to break Janowicz's serve, the Pole took the opening set in the tiebreak, following a double fault from Murray. However Murray managed to up his level of play, and won the next three sets, making it through to his second consecutive Wimbledon final, and third consecutive major final against Novak Djokovic.[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-227)

Despite the Serb being the favourite to win the title throughout the Championships, Murray overcame Djokovic in a straight sets match that lasted over three hours, to become the first British winner of the men's singles title since Fred Perry in 1936, the first Scot of either sex to win a Wimbledon singles title since  [Harold Mahony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Mahony "Harold Mahony")  in 1896, and to extend his winning streak on grass to 18 matches.[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-228)

At the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2013 US Open – Men's Singles"), Murray entered a Grand Slam tournament as defending champion for the first time, and started strongly with a straight sets win against  [Michaël Llodra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micha%C3%ABl_Llodra "Michaël Llodra"). He backed this up with wins over  [Leonardo Mayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonardo_Mayer "Leonardo Mayer"), Florian Mayer and  [Denis Istomin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Istomin "Denis Istomin")  to reach the quarter-finals at a major for the 11th straight tournament. In the last 8, Murray faced Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland, but lost in straight sets, ending Murray's streak of four consecutive major finals.[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-229)  Following his disappointing run of form on hard courts, Murray next joined the  [Great Britain Davis Cup team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain_Davis_Cup_team "Great Britain Davis Cup team")  in their  [World Group Play-off](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Davis_Cup_World_Group_Play-offs "2013 Davis Cup World Group Play-offs")  tie on clay against  [Croatia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatia_Davis_Cup_team "Croatia Davis Cup team"), where he played in two singles and the doubles rubbers. After defeating 16-year-old  [Borna Ćorić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borna_%C4%86ori%C4%87 "Borna Ćorić")  in straight sets, Murray teamed up with  [Colin Fleming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colin_Fleming "Colin Fleming")  to defeat Croatian number 1 Ivan Dodig and  [Mate Pavić](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mate_Pavi%C4%87 "Mate Pavić")  in the doubles, and take a 2–1 lead in the tie. Murray then sealed Britain's return to the  [World Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2014 Davis Cup World Group")  by defeating Dodig in straight sets.[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-230)

Following the Davis Cup, Murray's season was cut short by his decision to undergo surgery, in order to sort out the lower back problems that had caused him problems since the early stages of the previous season. After being forced to withdraw from the French Open in May, the injury flared up again during the US Open and later during the Davis Cup World Group Play-offs, Murray made the decision that surgery was the best way to sort the problem out for the long-term.[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-231)  Following the conclusion of the 2013 season, Murray was voted the  [2013 BBC Sport Personality of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year_Award "2013 BBC Sports Personality of the Year Award"), after having been heavy favourite since the nominees were announced.[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-232)

### 2014: 30th career title and out of top 10
Main article:  [2014 Andy Murray tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Andy_Murray_tennis_season "2014 Andy Murray tennis season")

Murray started his  [season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour "2014 ATP World Tour")  at the  [Qatar Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Qatar_ExxonMobil_Open "2014 Qatar ExxonMobil Open")  in Doha. In the first round, he defeated  [Mousa Shanan Zayed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mousa_Shanan_Zayed "Mousa Shanan Zayed")  in straight sets in 37 minutes without dropping a single game, but was defeated in three sets by No. 40 Florian Mayer in the second round, despite being a set and a break up three games into the second set.[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-233)  He then played a warm-up match at the  [2014 AAMI Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_AAMI_Classic "2014 AAMI Classic")  in Kooyong against No. 43 Lleyton Hewitt, losing in two close tiebreaks.

He next headed to Melbourne for the  [2014 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2014 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), where he drew the No. 112,  [Go Soeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Go_Soeda "Go Soeda")  of Japan. Despite worries that he was not match-fit, Murray got off to a strong start, dispatching the Japanese number 2 in under 90 minutes, losing just 5 games in the process. He next went on to defeat  [Vincent Millot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vincent_Millot "Vincent Millot")  and Feliciano López respectively in straight sets. In the fourth round, Murray dropped his first set of the tournament on his way to beating  [Stephane Robert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephane_Robert "Stephane Robert")  in four sets to set up a meeting with long-standing rival Roger Federer in the quarter-finals. Despite saving two match points to take the third set, he ultimately went out in four, ending his streak of four consecutive Australian Open semi-finals.[[234]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-234)  As a result of losing before the final, Murray fell to No. 6, falling out of the top 5 for the first time since 2008.

He next headed to the United States to compete in the  [Davis Cup World Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Davis_Cup_World_Group#United_States_vs._Great_Britain "2014 Davis Cup World Group")  first round with  [Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain_Davis_Cup_team "Great Britain Davis Cup team"), who went into the tie as outsiders. Murray won both of his ties against  [Donald Young](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Young_(tennis) "Donald Young (tennis)")  and Sam Querrey respectively, helping Britain to their first Davis Cup quarter-final since 1986.[[235]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-235)  Murray's next tournament was the  [Rotterdam Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament "2014 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament")  after receiving a late wild card, however he lost to Marin Čilić in straight sets in the quarter-finals. His following competition, the  [Mexican Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Abierto_Mexicano_Telcel "2014 Abierto Mexicano Telcel")  in Acapulco, ended in a semi-final defeat by Grigor Dimitrov in a thrilling three-setter that required two tiebreakers to decide the final two sets.

At  [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles#Section_2 "2014 BNP Paribas Open – Men's Singles"), Murray struggled in his first two matches against  [Lukáš Rosol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luk%C3%A1%C5%A1_Rosol "Lukáš Rosol")  and  [Jiří Veselý](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ji%C5%99%C3%AD_Vesel%C3%BD "Jiří Veselý")  respectively, overcoming both in close three-set encounters to set up a fourth round clash with Canadian Milos Raonic, which he lost in three sets. Murray offered to play with  [2012 Wimbledon Doubles champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles#Finals "2012 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Doubles")  [Jonathan Marray](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Marray "Jonathan Marray"), because Marray was unable to convince anyone to join him on court.[[236]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Wimbledon_2014:_Jonny_Marray's_doubles_trouble_ends_in_win_as_he_makes_second_round_with_John-Patrick_Smith-236)  For Murray and Marray's first competitive match together, they won a doubles clash against  [Gaël Monfils](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ga%C3%ABl_Monfils "Gaël Monfils")  and  [Juan Mónaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_M%C3%B3naco "Juan Mónaco")  only to lose in the  [second round](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Doubles#Bottom_half "2014 BNP Paribas Open – Men's Doubles")  to the No 2 seeds  [Alexander Peya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Peya "Alexander Peya")  and  [Bruno Soares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Soares "Bruno Soares").

In March, Murray split with coach Ivan Lendl, who had been widely praised for helping Murray achieve his goal of winning Grand Slam titles.[[237]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-237)  At the  [2014 Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Miami_Masters "2014 Miami Masters"), Murray defeated  [Matthew Ebden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_Ebden "Matthew Ebden"), Feliciano López and Jo Wilfried Tsonga but lost to Djokovic in the quarter-finals.[[238]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-238)  In the  [Davis Cup quarter-finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Davis_Cup_World_Group#Italy_vs._Great_Britain "2014 Davis Cup World Group")  against Italy, he beat  [Andreas Seppi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andreas_Seppi "Andreas Seppi")  in his first rubber, then teamed up with Colin Fleming to win the doubles rubber. Murray had only beaten one top ten player on clay, Nikolay Davydenko, back in 2009, and so in his final singles match, was stunned by  [Fabio Fognini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fabio_Fognini "Fabio Fognini")  in straight sets, which took Great Britain to the deciding final rubber.[[239]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Davis_2014_Out-239)  However, in this match his compatriot,  [James Ward](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Ward_(tennis) "James Ward (tennis)")  was defeated by Andreas Seppi, also in straight sets, knocking Murray and Great Britain out of the Davis Cup.[[239]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Davis_2014_Out-239)

Murray next competed at the  [Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Mutua_Madrid_Open "2014 Mutua Madrid Open")  and following his opening win, over Nicolas Almagro, he dedicated the victory to former player  [Elena Baltacha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elena_Baltacha "Elena Baltacha").[[240]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-240)[[241]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-241)  He then lost to qualifier  [Santiago Giraldo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santiago_Giraldo "Santiago Giraldo")  in the following round. Murray then reached the quarter-finals of the  [Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia "Internazionali BNL d'Italia")  where he lost to No. 1 Rafael Nadal in a tight match in which he had been up a break in the final set.[[242]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-242)  At the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_French_Open "2014 French Open"), Murray defeated  [Andrey Golubev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrey_Golubev "Andrey Golubev")  and Marinko Matosevic before edging out 28th seed Philipp Kohlschreiber 12–10 in the final set. This was the first time Murray had ever gone beyond 7–5 in a deciding set.[[243]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-243)  He followed this up with a straight sets win over Fernando Verdasco and then recorded a five set victory over Frenchman Gaël Monfils in the quarter-final, which saw Murray rise to No. 5 and equal his best ever  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Open "French Open")  by reaching the semi-finals. However, he subsequently lost to Nadal in straight sets, winning only 6 games in the match.[[244]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-244)  After losing the 2014 French Open semi-finals to Nadal, Murray appointed former women's world No. 1, and two-times slam titlist,  [Amélie Mauresmo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amelie_Mauresmo "Amelie Mauresmo")  as his coach[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-245)  in a 'historic move' which made Mauresmo the first woman to coach a top male tennis player.[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-AM_appointed-246)

After strong grass court seasons in 2012 and 2013, Murray was seeded third for the 2014 Wimbledon Championship, behind Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal, who were seeded first and second respectively.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-247)  He began his title defence with straight sets wins over  [David Goffin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Goffin "David Goffin")[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-248)  and  [Blaž Rola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bla%C5%BE_Rola "Blaž Rola"), defeating the latter for the loss of just two games.[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-249)  Murray continued his good form, defeating  [Roberto Bautista Agut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Bautista_Agut "Roberto Bautista Agut")[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-250)  and Kevin Anderson,[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-251)  the 27th and 20th seeds, again in straight sets to reach his seventh consecutive Wimbledon quarter-final. Murray's defence then came to a halt as Grigor Dimitrov ended his 17 match winning-streak on the grass of Wimbledon (this includes the 2012 Olympics) with a straight sets win, meaning Murray failed to reach the semi-finals for the first time since 2008.[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-252)  After his defeat at the Championships, Murray dropped to No. 10, his lowest ranking since 2008.[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-253)

Prior to the North American hard court swing, Murray announced he was extending his partnership with Amélie Mauresmo until the end of the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)"), but was ideally looking for a long-term deal.[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-254)  He also revealed he had only just returned to a full training schedule following his back surgery last September.[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-255)  Murray reached back-to-back quarter-finals at the  [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Rogers_Cup "2014 Rogers Cup")  and  [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Western_%26_Southern_Open "2014 Western & Southern Open"), losing to eventual champions Jo Wilfried Tsonga,[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-256)  after being a break up in the decider,[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-257)  and Roger Federer, after being two breaks up in the second set, respectively.[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-258)  He made it to the quarter-finals of the  [2014 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_US_Open_(tennis) "2014 US Open (tennis)"), losing to  [Novak Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic"), after earning his first top ten win of the year in the previous round against Jo Wilfried Tsonga.[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-259)  This was the first season since 2009 where Murray failed to reach a grand slam final. As a consequence Murray fell outside of the top 10 ranking places for the first time since June 2008.[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-260)

Murray took a wildcard into the inaugural  [Shenzhen Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ATP_Shenzhen_Open "2014 ATP Shenzhen Open")  in China, entering as the number 2 seed. Victories over  [Somdev Devvarman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somdev_Devvarman "Somdev Devvarman"),  [Lukáš Lacko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luk%C3%A1%C5%A1_Lacko "Lukáš Lacko")  and Juan Mónaco saw Murray reach his first final of the season, breaking a drought of 14 months following his title at Wimbledon. In the final he faced Tommy Robredo of Spain, the second final between the two. After saving five championship points in the second set tie break, Murray went on to win the title in three sets, Robredo's drop in fitness ultimately proving decisive.[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-261)  He then took his good form into  [Beijing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_China_Open_(tennis) "2014 China Open (tennis)"), where he reached the semi-finals before losing to Djokovic in straight sets,[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-262)  however he lost in the third round at the  [Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters "2014 Shanghai Rolex Masters")  to David Ferrer despite being a set up.[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-263)  Following his early exit in Shanghai, Murray took a wildcard into the  [Vienna Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Erste_Bank_Open "2014 Erste Bank Open")  in an attempt to claim a place at the  [ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2014 ATP World Tour Finals"). He reached the final, where he once again faced Ferrer, and triumphed in three sets for his second title of the season, and the 30th of his career.[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-264)  Murray defeated Ferrer again in the semi-finals of the  [Valencia Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valencia_Open_500 "Valencia Open 500")  to move into his third final in five weeks, and further strengthen his bid for a place at the season finale in London.[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-265)  In a repeat of the Shenzhen Open final, Murray again saved five championship points as he overcame Tommy Robredo in three sets.[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-266)  Murray then went on to reach the quarter-finals of the  [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_BNP_Paribas_Masters "2014 BNP Paribas Masters"), where he was eliminated by Djokovic in what was his 23rd match in the space of only 37 days.[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-267)  However, his win over Dimitrov in the third round had already guaranteed him a spot at the ATP World Tour Finals.[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-268)

At the  [ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2014 ATP World Tour Finals"), Murray lost his opening round robin match to  [Kei Nishikori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kei_Nishikori "Kei Nishikori")[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-269)  but won his second match against Milos Raonic.[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-270)  However, he lost his final group match against Federer in straight sets and only managed to win one game against him, marking his worst defeat since losing to Djokovic in the  [2007 Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Miami_Masters "2007 Miami Masters"), eliminating him from the tournament.[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-271)

Following the conclusion of the season, Murray mutually agreed a split with long-term backroom staff, training partner  [Dani Vallverdu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Vallverdu "Daniel Vallverdu")  and fitness coach Jez Green. They had been with him for five and seven years respectively but were both reported to have been unhappy at the lack of consultation they had been given about the appointment of Mauresmo.[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-272)  Murray also took part in the inaugural season of the  [International Premier Tennis League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Premier_Tennis_League "International Premier Tennis League"), representing the  [Manila Mavericks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manila_Mavericks "Manila Mavericks"), who had drafted him as an icon player in February.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-273)  Murray took part in the first three matches of the tournament which were all played in Manila.[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-274)

### 2015: Davis Cup champion and return to world No. 2

Main article:  [2015 Andy Murray tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Andy_Murray_tennis_season "2015 Andy Murray tennis season")

Murray began his year by winning an  [exhibition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Mubadala_World_Tennis_Championship "2015 Mubadala World Tennis Championship")  event in  [Abu Dhabi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abu_Dhabi "Abu Dhabi").[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-275)  He then played the  [Hopman Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Hopman_Cup "2015 Hopman Cup")  with  [Heather Watson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heather_Watson "Heather Watson")  and, despite winning all his singles matches in straight sets, they finished second in their group behind  [Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poland_at_the_Hopman_Cup "Poland at the Hopman Cup").[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-276)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/2015_Australian_Open_-_Andy_Murray_3.jpg/220px-2015_Australian_Open_-_Andy_Murray_3.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2015_Australian_Open_-_Andy_Murray_3.jpg)

Murray at the 2015 Australian Open

His first competitive tournament of the year was the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Australian_Open "2015 Australian Open"). He won his opening three matches in straight sets before defeating 11th seed Grigor Dimitrov to reach the quarter-final.[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-277)  Wins over  [Nick Kyrgios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Kyrgios "Nick Kyrgios")[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-278)  and Tomáš Berdych followed as Murray reached his fourth final at the tournament (three of which were against Djokovic) and the eighth grand slam final of his career.[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-279)  He lost the final to Novak Djokovic in four sets,[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-280)  however his run to the final saw his return to the top four in the world rankings for the first time in 12 months.[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-281)

Murray next participated in the  [Rotterdam Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament_%E2%80%93_Singles "2015 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament – Singles")  as the top seed, but he lost in the quarter-finals to Gilles Simon who ended a 12 match losing streak against Murray.[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-282)  Murray then played in the  [Dubai Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Dubai_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2015 Dubai Tennis Championships – Men's Singles")  but suffered another quarter-final defeat to 18-year-old Borna Ćorić and as a result, Murray slipped to No. 5 behind Rafael Nadal and Kei Nishikori.[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-283)[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-284)  Afterwards, Murray played the  [Davis Cup World Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2015 Davis Cup World Group")  in  [Glasgow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_Arena_and_Sir_Chris_Hoy_Velodrome "Commonwealth Arena and Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome")  against the  [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Davis_Cup_team "United States Davis Cup team"). He won both his matches against Donald Young and  [John Isner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Isner "John Isner"), allowing  [Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain_Davis_Cup_team "Great Britain Davis Cup team")  to progress to the quarter-finals for the second consecutive time with a 3–2 lead over the United States.[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-dc15us-285)

Murray then reached the semi-finals of the  [2015 Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_BNP_Paribas_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2015 BNP Paribas Open – Men's Singles"), overtaking  [Tim Henman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Henman "Tim Henman")'s record of 496 career wins to have the most career wins for a British man in the Open Era.[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-286)  However, he suffered a 6th consecutive defeat to Djokovic in straight sets.[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-287)  Murray then reached the final of the  [2015 Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Miami_Open "2015 Miami Open"), recording his 500th career win along the way to become the first British player to have 500 or more wins in the Open Era.[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-288)  He went on to lose the final to Djokovic, this time in three sets.[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-289)  Murray added  [Jonas Björkman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonas_Bj%C3%B6rkman "Jonas Björkman")  to his coaching staff in March initially on a five-week trail to help out in periods when Mauresmo was unavailable as she only agreed to work with him for 25 weeks.[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-290)  However, at the end of the Australian Open, Mauresmo had informed Murray that she was pregnant and he announced at the end of April, that Björkman would be his main coach for all of the grass court season and all of the US hard court swing, while Mauresmo would only be with the team for Wimbledon.[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-291)

Murray won his first ATP clay court title at the  [2015 BMW Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_BMW_Open "2015 BMW Open"). He defeated German Philipp Kohlschreiber in three close sets to become the first Briton since  [Buster Mottram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buster_Mottram "Buster Mottram")  in 1976 to win a tour level clay court event.[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-292)[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-293)  The following week he reached his second final on clay, at the  [Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Mutua_Madrid_Open "2015 Mutua Madrid Open")  after recording only his second and third victories over top 10 opposition on clay, against Raonic and Nishikori.[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-294)[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-295)  In the final, he defeated Rafael Nadal in straight sets for his first Madrid title on clay, and first ever clay court Masters 1000 title. The win was Murray's first over Nadal, Federer or Djokovic since Wimbledon 2013, and his first over Nadal on a clay court.[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-296)[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-297)

Murray continued his winning streak at the  [Italian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia "2015 Internazionali BNL d'Italia"), beating Jeremy Chardy in straight sets in his opening match, but then withdrew due to fatigue after having played nine matches in the space of 10 days. Murray then reached his third semi-final at the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2015 French Open – Men's Singles"), but lost to Djokovic in five sets after threatening a comeback from two sets to love down, ending his 15 match winning streak on clay.[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-298)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Andy_Murray_and_Jonas_Bj%C3%B6rkman_2%2C_Aegon_Championships%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Andy_Murray_and_Jonas_Bj%C3%B6rkman_2%2C_Aegon_Championships%2C_London%2C_UK_-_Diliff.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy_Murray_and_Jonas_Bj%C3%B6rkman_2,_Aegon_Championships,_London,_UK_-_Diliff.jpg)

Murray with new coach Jonas Björkman during practice at the 2015  [Aegon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aegon_Championships "Aegon Championships")

To start his grass court campaign, Murray went on to win a record tying fourth Queen's Club title, defeating the big serving South African Kevin Anderson in straight sets in the final.[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-299)  At the third grand slam of the year, the  [2015 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2015 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles"), Murray dropped only two sets on his way to setting up a semi-final clash with Roger Federer. Murray lost to the Swiss veteran in straight sets, gaining only one break point in the entire match.[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-300)

After Wimbledon, Murray returned to Queen's Club, to play for Great Britain against  [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France_Davis_Cup_team "France Davis Cup team")  in their Davis Cup quarter-final tie. Great Britain went 1–0 down when James Ward lost to Gilles Simon in straight sets, however Murray levelled the tie with a victory against Jo-Wilfried Tsonga. Murray then teamed up with his brother Jamie to win the doubles rubber, coming back from a set down to defeat Tsonga and Nicolas Mahut in four sets, giving Britain a crucial 2–1 lead going into the final day. He then faced Simon in the fourth rubber and after initially being a set and a break down, he suddenly found his form again towards the end of the second set and eventually won in four sets, winning 12 of the last 15 games in the process (with Simon struggling from an ankle injury). With a 3–1 lead over France, this resulted in Great Britain reaching their first Davis Cup semi-final since 1981.[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-dc15fr-301)

Murray next participated at the  [Citi Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Citi_Open "2015 Citi Open")  (for the first time since  [2006](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_Legg_Mason_Tennis_Classic_%E2%80%93_Singles "2006 Legg Mason Tennis Classic – Singles")), as the top seed and favourite to win the tournament. However, he suffered a defeat in his first match, losing to No. 53  [Teymuraz Gabashvili](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teymuraz_Gabashvili "Teymuraz Gabashvili")  in a final set tiebreak, despite serving for the match.[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-302)  In doubles, he partnered  [Daniel Nestor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Nestor "Daniel Nestor"), however they lost in the first round to the fourth seeds,  [Rohan Bopanna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohan_Bopanna "Rohan Bopanna")  and  [Florin Mergea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florin_Mergea "Florin Mergea"), also in three sets.[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-303)

He bounced back from this defeat by winning the  [Montreal Masters Rogers Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Rogers_Cup_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2015 Rogers Cup – Men's Singles"), defeating Tsonga and Nishikori in the quarter-finals and semi-finals respectively. He then prevailed in the final against Djokovic in three sets. This broke his eight-match, two-year losing streak against Djokovic (his last win against him being in the final of Wimbledon in 2013). In winning the title he also surpassed Federer in terms of ranking, becoming the world No. 2 for the first time in over two years. In doubles, he partnered Leander Paes and they won their first match against Chardy and Anderson, but were then defeated by Murray's brother Jamie and  [John Peers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Peers "John Peers")  in two sets – the first time the Murray brothers had competed against each other in a Tour-level match, a situation which Andy described as "awkward" and Jamie as "a bit weird".[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-304)

In the second Master Series tournament of the US Hard Court season, the  [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Western_%26_Southern_Open "2015 Western & Southern Open"), Murray defeated veteran Mardy Fish in the second round, and then beat both Grigor Dimitrov and Richard Gasquet in three-set matches, having to come from a set down on both occasions, while Dimitrov had served for the match in the deciding set. In the semi-final, he lost to defending champion Roger Federer in straight sets, and after Federer went on to win the tournament, this result saw Murray return to the No. 3 ranking and seeding for the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_US_Open_(tennis) "2015 US Open (tennis)"). At the US Open, Murray beat Nick Kyrgios in four sets before beating  [Adrian Mannarino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Mannarino "Adrian Mannarino")  in five sets after being two sets down, equaling Federer for winning eight matches from two sets to love down. He then beat  [Thomaz Bellucci](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomaz_Bellucci "Thomaz Bellucci")  in straight sets but suffered a defeat in the fourth round to Kevin Anderson in four sets. This ended Murray's five-year run of 18 consecutive Grand Slam quarter-finals (not counting his withdrawal from the  [2013 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2013 French Open – Men's Singles")) since his third round loss to Stan Wawrinka in the  [2010 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2010 US Open – Men's Singles").[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-305)

Playing against Australia in the semi-finals of the  [Davis Cup World Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2015 Davis Cup World Group")  in Glasgow, Murray won both his singles rubbers in straight sets, against  [Thanasi Kokkinakis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanasi_Kokkinakis "Thanasi Kokkinakis")  and  [Bernard Tomic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Tomic "Bernard Tomic").[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-dc15oz1-306)  He also partnered his brother Jamie, and they won in five sets against the pairing of  [Sam Groth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Groth "Sam Groth")  and Lleyton Hewitt, the results guiding  [Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain_Davis_Cup_team "Great Britain Davis Cup team")  to the  [Davis Cup final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Davis_Cup_World_Group#Belgium_vs._Great_Britain "2015 Davis Cup World Group")  for the first time since 1978 with a 3–2 lead over Australia.[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-dc15oz2-307)

After losing in the semi-finals of the  [Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai_Masters_(tennis) "Shanghai Masters (tennis)")  to Djokovic in straight sets, Murray reached the finals of the  [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_BNP_Paribas_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2015 BNP Paribas Masters – Singles")  for the lost of just one set, with victories against Borna Ćorić, David Goffin and David Ferrer. After a three set win over Richard Gasquet, he joined Novak Djokovic, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal as the only players to reach the semi-finals (or better) at all nine of the  [ATP World Tour Masters 1000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Masters_1000 "ATP World Tour Masters 1000")  tournaments, and also ensured that he compiled his best match record in a single season.[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-308)  He then lost the final to Djokovic again in straight sets.

As the world No. 2, Murray participated in the  [ATP World Tour Finals in London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Tour_Finals "World Tour Finals"), and was drawn into the  [Ilie Năstase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ilie_N%C4%83stase "Ilie Năstase")  group with David Ferrer, Rafael Nadal and Stan Wawrinka. He went out in the round-robin stage, after defeating Ferrer and losing to Nadal and Wawrinka.[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-309)  However, after Federer failed to win the tournament, he finished the season ranked No. 2 for the first time.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-310)

In the Davis Cup final, Murray's victory over  [Ruben Bemelmans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruben_Bemelmans "Ruben Bemelmans")  in straight sets pulled Great Britain level in the final after  [Kyle Edmund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyle_Edmund "Kyle Edmund")  had lost the first singles rubber in five sets, played on indoor clay courts at Ghent. He then partnered his brother Jamie in a four-set victory over the pairing of  [Steve Darcis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Darcis "Steve Darcis")  and David Goffin, before defeating Goffin again in the reverse singles on Sunday, thus ensuring a 3–1 victory for Great Britain, their first Davis Cup title since  [1936](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1936_Davis_Cup "1936 Davis Cup")  and their tenth overall.[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-clinch-311)  Murray also became only the third person since the current Davis Cup format was introduced to win all eight of his singles rubbers in a Davis Cup season, after  [John McEnroe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McEnroe "John McEnroe")  and  [Mats Wilander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mats_Wilander "Mats Wilander").[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-312)

### 2016: Second Wimbledon and Olympic Gold, ascent to world No. 1

Main article:  [2016 Andy Murray tennis season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Andy_Murray_tennis_season "2016 Andy Murray tennis season")

Murray began his 2016 season by playing in the  [Hopman Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Hopman_Cup "2016 Hopman Cup"), pairing up with Heather Watson again. However, they finished second in their group after losing their tie to eventual champions Nick Kyrgios and  [Daria Gavrilova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daria_Gavrilova "Daria Gavrilova")  from Australia.[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-313)

Murray played his first competitive tournament of 2016 at the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Open "Australian Open")  where he was aiming to win his first title there after four runner-up finishes. He went on to reach his fifth  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Open "Australian Open")  final with victories over  [Alexander Zverev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Zverev_Jr. "Alexander Zverev Jr."),  [Sam Groth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Groth "Sam Groth"),  [João Sousa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Sousa "João Sousa"),  [Bernard Tomic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernard_Tomic "Bernard Tomic"),  [David Ferrer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrer "David Ferrer")  and  [Milos Raonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milos_Raonic "Milos Raonic"), dropping four sets along the way. However, in a rematch of the previous year final, he was unable to win his first title as he lost in the final to an in-form  [Novak Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic")  (who won a record-equalling sixth title) in straight sets.[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-314)  He became the second man in the  [Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Era_(tennis) "Open Era (tennis)")  (after  [Ivan Lendl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Lendl "Ivan Lendl")) to lose five Grand Slam finals at one event, and the only one not to have won the title. Subsequently, in February, Murray appointed  [Jamie Delgado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Delgado "Jamie Delgado")  as an assistant coach.[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-315)

Murray then played at  [2016 Davis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Davis_Cup "2016 Davis Cup")  defeating  [Taro Daniel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taro_Daniel "Taro Daniel")  in straight sets and Kei Nishikori in five sets. Murray then competed at the first  [Masters 1000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masters_1000 "Masters 1000")  of the year at the  [2016 Indian Wells Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Indian_Wells_Masters "2016 Indian Wells Masters"). He defeated  [Marcel Granollers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcel_Granollers "Marcel Granollers")  in the second round in straight sets but had an early loss to  [Federico Delbonis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federico_Delbonis "Federico Delbonis")  in the third round. Murray then played at the  [2016 Miami Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Miami_Open "2016 Miami Open")  as the 2nd seed. He defeated  [Denis Istomin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denis_Istomin "Denis Istomin")  in the second round in straight sets but had another early loss, to 26th seed  [Grigor Dimitrov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigor_Dimitrov "Grigor Dimitrov"), despite taking the first set.[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-316)

Murray began his clay court season at the  [2016 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters "2016 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters")  as the 2nd seed. Murray struggled in his second round match against  [Pierre-Hugues Herbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre-Hugues_Herbert "Pierre-Hugues Herbert")  but Murray came through in 3 sets. Murray struggled again in his third round match against 16th seed  [Benoît Paire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beno%C3%AEt_Paire "Benoît Paire")  as Murray was down a set and two breaks. Paire also served for the match in the third set but Murray still came through in 3 sets. Murray then defeated 10th seed Milos Raonic in straight sets in the quarter-finals. In the semi-finals Murray lost to 5th seed and eventual champion Rafael Nadal despite winning the first set. Murray then played at the  [2016 Mutua Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Mutua_Madrid_Open "2016 Mutua Madrid Open")  as the 2nd seed and the defending champion. Murray defeated qualifier Radek Štěpánek in three sets. He then proceeded to the semi-finals after defeating 16th seed Gilles Simon and 8th seed Tomáš Berdych both in straight sets. In the semi-finals Murray defeated Nadal in straight sets who Murray had lost to earlier in the year. In the final Murray lost to number 1 seed Novak Djokovic in three sets. This loss dropped Murray from second to third in the ATP Rankings. Shortly afterwards Mauresmo and Murray issued a joint statement announcing that they had "mutually agreed" to end their coaching partnership.[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-317)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/AndyMurrayWimbledon2016.jpg/220px-AndyMurrayWimbledon2016.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:AndyMurrayWimbledon2016.jpg)

In 2016, Murray won his second Wimbledon title, beating Milos Raonic 6–4, 7–6(3), 7–6(2) in the final

Murray regained his number two ranking after he won the  [2016 Internazionali BNL d'Italia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia "2016 Internazionali BNL d'Italia")  for his 1st title of the season and 36th overall. He defeated  [Mikhail Kukushkin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mikhail_Kukushkin "Mikhail Kukushkin"), Jérémy Chardy, 12th seed David Goffin,  [Lucas Pouille](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucas_Pouille "Lucas Pouille"), and number 1 seed Djokovic all in straight sets. This was his first win over Djokovic on clay and became the first British player since  [Virginia Wade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Wade "Virginia Wade")  in 1971 to win the title and the first British man since  [George Patrick Hughes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Patrick_Hughes "George Patrick Hughes")  in 1931.[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-318)  Murray then moved on to the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open "2016 French Open")  where he struggled in the opening rounds coming through two five-set matches against Štěpánek and French wildcard  [Mathias Bourgue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathias_Bourgue "Mathias Bourgue"). He came through in straight sets against big servers  [Ivo Karlović](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivo_Karlovi%C4%87 "Ivo Karlović")  and John Isner to reach the quarter-finals where he beat home favourite Richard Gasquet in four sets to set up a semi-final clash against defending champion Stanislas Wawrinka. Murray defeated Wawrinka in four sets to become the first male British player since Bunny Austin in 1937, to reach a French Open final.[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-319)  He was unable to win his maiden French Open final, losing to Djokovic in four sets.

In June 2016, Ivan Lendl agreed to return to his former role as Murray's coach.[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-320)  Murray started his grass season at the  [2016 Aegon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Aegon_Championships "2016 Aegon Championships")  as the 1st seed and the defending champion. Murray defeated Nicolas Mahut in straight sets despite facing a set point in the first set and three set points in the second set. He then defeated his countryman  [Aljaž Bedene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alja%C5%BE_Bedene "Aljaž Bedene")  in straight sets. He then had three set wins over Kyle Edmund, another countryman, and No. 5 seed Marin Čilić. In the final he was down a set and a break to 3rd seed Milos Raonic. Murray still managed to come back and win a record 5th  [Queen's Club Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club_Championships "Queen's Club Championships")  and it was also his 2nd title in 2016. Murray then played at the third major of the year at the  [2016 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Wimbledon_Championships "2016 Wimbledon Championships")  as the 2nd seed. Murray had straight set wins over  [Liam Broady](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liam_Broady "Liam Broady"), Lu Yen-hsun,  [John Millman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Millman "John Millman"), and Nick Kyrgios in the first four rounds.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-321)  Murray then defeated 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in five sets in the quarter-final[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-322)  and 10th seed Tomáš Berdych in straight sets to reach his third straight major final. In the final on 10 July, Murray defeated Raonic in straight sets to win his second  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon")  title and third major title overall.[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-ESPN-323)  His Wimbledon crown was his 3rd title of the season and 38th career Tour title.

Murray next played at the  [Rio Olympic Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles"). He became the first player, male or female, to win two gold medals in the tennis singles events by defeating Juan Martín del Potro in the final, which lasted over four hours.[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-324)  The win was his 3rd consecutive title and 4th title of the season. Murray then entered the US Open and beat Lukas Rosol, Marcel Granollers,  [Paolo Lorenzi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paolo_Lorenzi "Paolo Lorenzi")  and Grigor Dimitrov in the first four rounds. However his run came to an end when he lost to sixth seed Kei Nishikori in five sets despite holding a two sets to one lead.

Murray  [carrying the flag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_flag_bearers_for_Great_Britain_at_the_Olympics "List of flag bearers for Great Britain at the Olympics")  on behalf of athletes from the Great Britain during the  [parade of nation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics_Parade_of_Nations "2016 Summer Olympics Parade of Nations")  within the  [2016 Summer Olympics opening ceremony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony "2016 Summer Olympics opening ceremony")

His next activity was the  [2016 Davis Cup semi-final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2016 Davis Cup World Group")  in Glasgow against Argentina. He lost the opening rubber against Juan Martín del Potro in five sets.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-325)  After Great Britain lost the second rubber as well, he teamed up with his brother Jamie to beat del Potro and Leonardo Mayer in the third rubber in four sets.[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-326)  He then won the fourth rubber against  [Guido Pella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guido_Pella "Guido Pella")  in straight sets,[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-327)  though Great Britain eventually lost the tie.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-328)  Murray then won the  [China Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_China_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 China Open – Men's Singles")  for his fifth title of 2016 and 40th career tour title. He defeated  [Andreas Seppi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andreas_Seppi "Andreas Seppi"),  [Andrey Kuznetsov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrey_Kuznetsov_(tennis) "Andrey Kuznetsov (tennis)"),  [Kyle Edmund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyle_Edmund "Kyle Edmund"),  [David Ferrer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Ferrer "David Ferrer"), and  [Grigor Dimitrov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigor_Dimitrov "Grigor Dimitrov")  all in straight sets. Murray then backed this up with a tournament win at the  [Shanghai Rolex Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles")  defeating  [Steve Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Johnson_(tennis) "Steve Johnson (tennis)"),  [Lucas Pouille](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucas_Pouille "Lucas Pouille"),  [David Goffin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Goffin "David Goffin"),  [Gilles Simon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilles_Simon "Gilles Simon"), and  [Roberto Bautista Agut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Bautista_Agut "Roberto Bautista Agut")  all in straight sets to capture his 13th masters title and 3rd title in Shanghai. This marked his 6th title of 2016 and drew him even with former No. 1 Stefan Edberg at No. 15 on the Open Era titles list with 41 Tour titles each.

Murray brought his win streak to 15 consecutive match wins by winning the Erste Bank Open for his seventh tour title of the 2016 season. His tournament started slowly with three-set wins over  [Martin Klizan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Klizan "Martin Klizan")  and Gilles Simon in the first two rounds. However, a decisive win over  [John Isner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Isner "John Isner")  in the quarter-final and a walkover due to David Ferrer's withdrawal with a leg injury saw Murray reach the final.[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-329)  There he defeated Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, for his third title in succession.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-330)  The result saw Murray win seven titles in a single season for the first time in his career, and move to solo 15th on the  [all-time list of singles titles in the Open Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_players_with_most_titles_in_the_Open_Era#Men "Tennis players with most titles in the Open Era"), breaking a tie with former world No. 1  [Stefan Edberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stefan_Edberg "Stefan Edberg").[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-331)

Murray entered the  [Paris Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_BNP_Paribas_Masters "2016 BNP Paribas Masters")  knowing that in the event of Djokovic not reaching the final, winning the title would be enough to see him crowned world No. 1 for the first time. After reaching the quarter-finals, courtesy of wins over Fernando Verdasco and  [Lucas Pouille](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucas_Pouille "Lucas Pouille"), Murray faced Berdych for a place in the semi-finals, winning in straight sets. Meanwhile, Djokovic lost to  [Marin Cilic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marin_Cilic "Marin Cilic"), meaning that Murray would replace Djokovic at the top of the rankings should he reach the final. He was due to face Milos Raonic in the semi-finals. However, Raonic withdrew prior to the start of the match, giving Murray a walkover. As a result, Murray became the first British man to reach No. 1 since the introduction of the rankings in 1973.[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-332)  Murray then defeated John Isner in the final in 3 sets to win his fourth consecutive tournament and first Paris Masters title.[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-333)  In November 2016, Murray reached the  [final of the ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles")  for the first time before winning against Novak Djokovic in two sets, thus reaching  [year-end No. 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ATP_number_1_ranked_singles_tennis_players#Year-end_No._1 "List of ATP number 1 ranked singles tennis players")[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-334)  and in doing so, becoming the first player to win a Grand Slam, the ATP World Tour Finals, the men's singles at the Olympic Games and a Masters 1000 title in the same calendar year. The  [International Tennis Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation "International Tennis Federation")  recognised Murray as their men's  [2016 ITF men's world champion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITF_World_Champions "ITF World Champions"), the first time Murray had achieved this honour.

that November, as a result of his inactivity, his ranking fell sharply to No. 16, his lowest ranking since May 2008.[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-365)[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-366)  Murray returned to the court to play a charity match against Federer in  [Glasgow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glasgow "Glasgow")  and expressed his hope to return to the tour in  [Brisbane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane").[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-367)  The following week, he and Ivan Lendl announced that they had mutually ended their coaching arrangement for a second time.[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-368)

### 2018: Hip surgery, out of top 800 and return to tour

Murray withdrew from the  [Brisbane International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Brisbane_International "2018 Brisbane International")  and  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Australian_Open "2018 Australian Open")  due to hip injury.[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-369)  In a post on  [Instagram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instagram "Instagram"), Murray explained that rehab was one option for recovery. He added that hip surgery was also an option but that the chances of a successful outcome were not as high.[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-auto-370)[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-371)  On 8 January, Murray announced on Instagram he had undergone hip surgery.[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-auto-370)[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-372)

In March, Murray lost his British No. 1 ranking for the first time since 2006, to  [Kyle Edmund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyle_Edmund "Kyle Edmund")  .[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-373)  Later that month, Murray said he was making progress after several days of playing at the Mouratoglou Academy in  [Nice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nice "Nice")  after posting pictures of himself practising against Aidan McHugh, a British junior player, on Instagram.[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-374)[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-375)  He then announced he would play his first ATP tournament since hip surgery at the  [Rosmalen Grass Court Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosmalen_Grass_Court_Championships "Rosmalen Grass Court Championships")  in June,[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-376)[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-377)  although he later withdrew saying he was not quite ready and wanted to be 100%.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-378)  However, he later announced he would make his return at the  [Queen's Club Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club_Championships "Queen's Club Championships"). He then entered the  [Washington Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Open_(tennis) "Washington Open (tennis)"), where he won his first round match against  [Mackenzie McDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mackenzie_McDonald "Mackenzie McDonald")  in three sets.[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-383)  He then faced  [Kyle Edmund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyle_Edmund "Kyle Edmund"), who had dealt him his last defeat at Eastbourne, overcoming him in three sets. He then withdrew from the tournament and the  [Canadian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Open_(tennis) "Canadian Open (tennis)")  the following week to continue his recovery and to focus on the  [Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters "Cincinnati Masters")  for which he was awarded a wildcard.
