### 2019: Second hip surgery, comeback and first title in two years

Murray travelled to  [Brisbane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane")  early in order to better prepare for the  [Brisbane International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brisbane_International "Brisbane International").[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-393)  He won his first round match against  [James Duckworth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Duckworth_(tennis) "James Duckworth (tennis)")  in straight sets but admitted post-match that he did not know how long he would be able to play top-class tennis.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-394)  Murray was defeated in the next round by  [Daniil Medvedev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniil_Medvedev "Daniil Medvedev"), at that time ranked 16th in the world.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-395)

On 11 January 2019, at a press conference just prior to the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2019 Australian Open – Men's Singles"), an emotional Murray announced that he could possibly retire from professional tennis due to struggling physically for a "long time", particularly with his hip injury. He said that he had been suffering with hip pain on a daily basis, and that it caused him to struggle with tasks like putting his shoes and socks on.[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-surprise-396)  He spoke of the possibility of a second hip surgery, but expressed doubt this would be a viable option to prolong his career, merely allowing him to "have a better quality of life, and be out of pain".[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbclast19-397)  He hoped to make it through to  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships "2019 Wimbledon Championships"),[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-bbclast19-397)[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-lastword19-398)  but that the Australian Open could be his final tournament if he was not able to last until the summer, stating: "I'm not sure I can play through the pain for another four or five months".[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-surprise-396)  Active and retired tennis players, including Juan Martín del Potro, Kyle Edmund,  [Bilie Jean King](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billie_Jean_King "Billie Jean King")  and the other members of the 'Big Four' paid tribute to Murray upon his announcement.[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-399)[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-400)[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-401)

Murray entered the singles of the Australian Open, however lost his opening match against 22nd seed  [Roberto Bautista Agut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Bautista_Agut "Roberto Bautista Agut")  in a four-hour, five-set 'epic'. At its conclusion, a video montage of tributes featuring other top players Roger Federer, Novak Djokovic,  [Sloane Stephens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sloane_Stephens "Sloane Stephens")  and  [Caroline Wozniacki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caroline_Wozniacki "Caroline Wozniacki")  played in deference to his impending retirement.[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-402)  In his post-match interview, he stated that he was considering a second hip surgery, and had not yet ruled out a return to the sport upon recovering from the operation.[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-403)

[Bob Bryan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Bryan "Bob Bryan")  urged Murray to have the "[Birmingham hip (BHR)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birmingham_Hip_Resurfacing "Birmingham Hip Resurfacing")" operation he underwent in August 2018, involving a cobalt-chrome metal cap being placed over the femur with a matching metal cup in the acetabulum (a conservative bone-saving alternative to a traditional Total Hip Replacement). Bryan informed Murray that the BHR would improve his quality of life and may help him return to the professional tennis tour.[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-404)  On 29 January, Murray announced on Instagram that he had undergone hip resurfacing surgery in London and hoped that it would "be the end of my hip pain."[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-405)  On 4 February, in an interview with  _[The Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_,  [Professor Derek McMinn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_McMinn "Derek McMinn"), who invented the BHR implant and procedure, gave the opinion that Murray's chances of returning to competitive tennis should be "in the high 90 per cent".[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-406)  On 7 March, Murray stated in an interview that he was now free of pain in his hip as a result of the surgery and may therefore return to playing competitive tennis, but that any potential Wimbledon return would be dependent on how his hip felt, and that he would not rush his comeback and may test his condition by playing doubles.[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-407)

### Murray vs. Djokovic
Main article:  [Djokovic–Murray rivalry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Djokovic%E2%80%93Murray_rivalry "Djokovic–Murray rivalry")

[Novak Djokovic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novak_Djokovic "Novak Djokovic")  and Murray have met 36 times with Djokovic leading 25–11.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Novak_Djokovic_VS_Andy_Murray-426)[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-427)  Djokovic leads 5–1 on clay, 20–8 on hard courts, and Murray leads 2–0 on grass. The two are almost exactly the same age, with Murray being only a week older than Djokovic. They went to training camp together, and Murray won the first match they ever played as teenagers. The pair have met 19 times in finals, with Djokovic leading 11–8.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-Novak_Djokovic_VS_Andy_Murray-426)  Ten of the finals were at  [ATP Masters 1000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Masters_1000 "ATP Masters 1000")  events, and they are tied at 5–5. They have met in seven major finals: The  [2011 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open "2011 Australian Open"), the  [2012 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis) "2012 US Open (tennis)"), the  [2013 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Australian_Open "2013 Australian Open"), the  [2013 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships "2013 Wimbledon Championships"), the  [2015 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Australian_Open "2015 Australian Open"), the  [2016 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Australian_Open "2016 Australian Open"), and the  [2016 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open "2016 French Open"). Djokovic has won in Australia four times and their single French open final, Murray emerged as the victor at the US Open and Wimbledon. The former of Murray's victories was the longest ever final at the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)"), tying with the 1988 final played between Ivan Lendl and Mats Wilander at 4 hours and 53 minutes, while the latter was notable for being the first home triumph in men's singles at  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon")  since 1936.

They also played a nearly five-hour long semi-final match in the  [2012 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Australian_Open "2012 Australian Open"), which Djokovic won 7–5 in the fifth set after Murray led 2 sets to 1. Murray and Djokovic met again in 2012 at the  [London 2012 Olympic Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's singles"), with Murray winning in straight sets. During the final of the  [2012 Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters "2012 Shanghai Rolex Masters"), Murray held five championship points in the second set, however Djokovic saved each of them, forcing a deciding set. He eventually prevailed to win his first Shanghai Masters title, ending Murray's 12–0 winning streak at the event. The three set matches they played in  [Rome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Open_(tennis) "Italian Open (tennis)")  and  [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai_Masters_(tennis) "Shanghai Masters (tennis)")  in  [2011](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2011 Internazionali BNL d'Italia – Men's Singles")  and  [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2012 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles")  respectively were voted the ATP World Tour Match of the Year for each respective season.[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-428)[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-429)  Due to the tight competition between 2008 and 2013, many saw this as the emerging rivalry.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-430)[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-431)  Djokovic went on to dominate the rivalry after the 2013 Wimbledon final, winning 13 of their last 16 matches. In 2016, Murray suffered his 4th loss (his 5th total) in the final of the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 Australian Open – Men's Singles")  from Djokovic, then the Serbian defeated the British player in four sets in the  [Roland Garros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 French Open – Men's Singles")  final, where Djokovic won his first Roland Garros title and completed the Career Grand Slam.[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-432)[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-433)Murray and Djokovic met in the final at the year's end  [final of the ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_ATP_World_Tour_Finals_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 ATP World Tour Finals – Singles")  for the first time in their rivalry, where the winner would be granted the Year-end No. 1 status. Djokovic, dropped only one set en route to the final at the  [ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals "ATP World Tour Finals"), but lost in straight sets to Murray, who finished the year at No. 1 and became the first British player to achieve this feat.

### Murray vs. Federer

Murray and  [Roger Federer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer")  have met 25 times with Federer leading 14–11. Federer leads 12–10 on hard courts, 2–1 on grass, and they have never met on clay. After Federer won the first professional match they played, Murray dominated the first half of the rivalry, winning 8 of their first 13 matches from 2005 until 2010. The second half of the rivalry has been dominated by Federer, who since won 9 of their last 12 matches from 2010, and has led their rivalry since the  [2014 ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_ATP_World_Tour_Finals "2014 ATP World Tour Finals").[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-h2hFed-434)  Federer leads 5–3 in finals, having won each of their Grand Slam Final meetings at the  [2008 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_US_Open_(tennis) "2008 US Open (tennis)")[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-autogenerated2-122)  and  [2010 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Australian_Open "2010 Australian Open"), both of which Federer won in straight sets, and the  [2012 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships "2012 Wimbledon Championships"), where Murray took the first set, but ended up losing in 4 sets. Murray leads 6–3 in ATP 1000 tournaments and 2–0 in finals. They have met five times at the  [ATP World Tour Finals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_Finals "ATP World Tour Finals"), with Murray winning in Shanghai in 2008[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-435)  and Federer coming out victorious in London in 2009, 2010, 2012, and in 2014.

In August 2012, Murray met Federer in the  [final of the London 2012 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_singles "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's singles")  at Wimbledon Centre Court, just four weeks after the  [2012 Wimbledon Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles_final "2012 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles final"), in which Federer had defeated Murray to win his record-tying 7th title at the All-England Club. Murray defeated Federer in straight sets to win the gold medal, denying Federer a  [Career Golden Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Career_Golden_Slam "Career Golden Slam"). In 2013 Murray beat Federer for the first time in a major in the semi-finals of the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Australian_Open "2013 Australian Open"), prevailing in five sets after Federer had come back twice from a set down.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-436)  Their last grand slam meeting was at the  [2015 Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships "2015 Wimbledon Championships")  semi-finals, where a dominant Federer defeated Murray in straight sets, earning a place in his 10th Wimbledon final. Murray is one of only three players to have recorded 10 or more victories over Federer, the other two being Nadal and Djokovic. Their most recent meeting took place at the  [2015 Cincinnati Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Western_%26_Southern_Open "2015 Western & Southern Open")  semi-finals, with Federer winning the match in two close sets, recording his fifth consecutive victory over Murray.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-h2hFed-434)

### Murray vs. Nadal

Murray has played against  [Rafael Nadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal "Rafael Nadal")  on 24 occasions since  [2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_ATP_Tour "2007 ATP Tour"), with Nadal leading 17–7. Nadal leads 7–2 on clay, 3–0 on grass and 7–5 on hard courts. The pair regularly meet at  [Grand Slam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis) "Grand Slam (tennis)")  level, with nine out of their twenty-four meetings coming in slams, with Nadal leading 7–2 (3–0 at  [Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon"), 2–0 at the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Open "French Open"), 1–1 at the  [Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Open "Australian Open")  and 1–1 at the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Open_(tennis) "US Open (tennis)")).[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-437)  Eight of these nine appearances have been at quarter-final and semi-final level. They have never met in a slam final, however, Murray leads 3–1 in  [ATP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_Tennis_Professionals "Association of Tennis Professionals")  finals, with Nadal winning at  [Indian Wells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_BNP_Paribas_Open "2009 BNP Paribas Open")  in  [2009](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ATP_World_Tour "2009 ATP World Tour")[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-438)  and Murray winning in  [Rotterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_ABN_AMRO_World_Tennis_Tournament "2009 ABN AMRO World Tennis Tournament")  the same year,[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-439)  [Tokyo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships "2011 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships")[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-440)  in  [2011](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_ATP_World_Tour "2011 ATP World Tour"), and at  [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Mutua_Madrid_Open "2015 Mutua Madrid Open")  in  [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_ATP_World_Tour "2015 ATP World Tour").

Murray lost three consecutive Grand Slam semi-finals to Nadal in 2011 from the  [French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_French_Open "2011 French Open")  to the  [US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_US_Open_(tennis) "2011 US Open (tennis)"). The pair had not met for three years since the final of the  [2011 Japan Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Rakuten_Japan_Open_Tennis_Championships "2011 Rakuten Japan Open Tennis Championships")  until the quarter-finals of the  [2014 Rome Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia "2014 Internazionali BNL d'Italia"), although they were scheduled to meet in the semi-final of the  [2012 Miami Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Miami_Masters "2012 Miami Masters")  before Nadal withdrew with injury.[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-441)  At the semi-final stage of the  [2014 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_French_Open "2014 French Open"), Nadal triumphed in a dominant straight sets win for the loss of just 6 games. In one of their most recent meetings, Murray beat Nadal for the first time on clay, and the first time in a Masters 1000 final, at the  [Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Mutua_Madrid_Open "2015 Mutua Madrid Open")  in 2015.[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-442)  Murray fell to Nadal in the semi-finals of the  [2016 Monte Carlo Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Monte-Carlo_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2016 Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters – Singles"), despite taking the first set.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-443)  Three weeks later they met again at the semi-final stage of the  [2016 Madrid Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's Singles"), this time Murray winning the match in straight sets.[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-444)

### Murray vs. Wawrinka

Murray and  [Stan Wawrinka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stan_Wawrinka "Stan Wawrinka")  have played 20 times with Murray leading 12–8. Murray leads 8–4 on hard courts and 3–0 on grass courts while Wawrinka leads 4–1 on clay courts. They have also met six times in Grand Slam tournaments with each player winning three matches.[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-445)  They have contested some close matches and one of their most notable matches was in the  [2009 Wimbledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2009 Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles")  fourth round which Murray won in five sets and was the first men's match to be played under the Wimbledon roof, having the latest finish for a Wimbledon match at the time.[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-446)  Wawrinka also ended Murray's title defense at the  [2013 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2013 US Open – Men's Singles")  quarter-finals with a comfortable straight sets victory.[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-447)  Other close matches the two have contested include the  [2010 US Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2010 US Open – Men's Singles")  which Wawrinka won in four sets. Murray won the  [2008 Canada Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Rogers_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2008 Rogers Masters – Singles")  and  [2011 Shanghai Masters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Shanghai_Rolex_Masters_%E2%80%93_Singles "2011 Shanghai Rolex Masters – Singles").

While Murray has led the majority of the rivalry, Wawrinka won their first two matches and beat Murray three consecutive times between 2013 and 2015, winning all of them in straight sets, until Murray ended the losing streak at the  [2016 French Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2016 French Open – Men's Singles"), beating the defending champion Wawrinka in four sets to reach his first ever French Open final and become the first British man to do so since 1937. Their most recent match was played in the final of the  [2019 European Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2019 European Open – Singles"), which Murray won in three sets. Due to this match-up and since both players each have three Grand Slam titles, Wawrinka has been identified by some, including Djokovic, as a potential contender to turn the  [Big Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis) "Big Four (tennis)")  tennis quartet into a "Big Five", although Wawrinka himself has downplayed those suggestions, stating that he is still far behind them.[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-448)[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-449)

## Playing style

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Flickr_-_Carine06_-_Andy_Murray_%2810%29.jpg/170px-Flickr_-_Carine06_-_Andy_Murray_%2810%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Carine06_-_Andy_Murray_(10).jpg)

At the  [Boodles Challenge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boodles_Challenge "Boodles Challenge"), Stoke Park, June 2012

Murray plays an  [all-court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_strategy#All-court_player "Tennis strategy")  game with an emphasis on  [defensive baseline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterpuncher "Counterpuncher")  play, and in 2009 professional tennis coach  [Paul Annacone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Annacone "Paul Annacone")  stated that Murray "may be the best counterpuncher on tour today."[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-450)[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-No_surface_tension_as_Murray_looks_to_shed_his_feet_of_clay-451)  His strengths include groundstrokes with low error rate, the ability to anticipate and react, and his transition from defence to offence with speed, which enables him to hit winners from defensive positions. His playing style has been likened to that of  [Miloslav Mečíř](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miloslav_Me%C4%8D%C3%AD%C5%99 "Miloslav Mečíř"). Murray also has one of the best two-handed backhands on the tour, with dynamic stroke execution[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-452)  while he primarily uses his forehand, which is more passive, and a sliced backhand to let opponents play into his defensive game before playing more offensively.[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-453)  [Tim Henman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Henman "Tim Henman")  stated in 2013 that Murray may have the best  [lob](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lob_(tennis) "Lob (tennis)")  in the game, succeeding  [Lleyton Hewitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lleyton_Hewitt "Lleyton Hewitt"). Murray's tactics often involve passive exchanges from the baseline. He is capable of injecting sudden pace into his groundstrokes to surprise his opponents who are used to the slow rally. Murray is also one of the top returners in the game, often able to block back fast serves with his excellent reach and ability to anticipate. For this reason, Murray is rarely aced.[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-454)

Murray is known for being one of the most intelligent tacticians on the court, often constructing points.[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-455)[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-456)  Other strengths in his game, although not huge parts of his game, include his  [drop shot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drop_shot "Drop shot")[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-457)  and net game.[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-458)  As he plays predominantly from the baseline, he usually approaches the net to  [volley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volley_(tennis) "Volley (tennis)")  when finishing points more quickly.[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-459)  Murray is most proficient on a fast surface, like grass, where he has won eight singles titles including the  [Wimbledon Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships, Wimbledon")  and the  [2012 Olympic Gold Medal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics "Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics"), although hard courts are his preferred surface.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-No_surface_tension_as_Murray_looks_to_shed_his_feet_of_clay-451)  He has worked hard since 2008 on improving his clay court game,[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-460)  ultimately winning his first clay titles during 2015 at  [Munich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_BMW_Open_%E2%80%93_Singles "2015 BMW Open – Singles")  and  [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Mutua_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2015 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's Singles"), as well as reaching his first French Open final during 2016. While Murray's  [serve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serve_(tennis) "Serve (tennis)")  is a major weapon for him, with his first serve reaching speeds of 130 mph or higher on some occasions and winning him many free points,[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-How_Andy_Murray_turned_a_second_serve_into_a_lethal_weapon-461)  it can become inconsistent when hit under pressure,[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-462)  especially with a more vulnerable and slower second serve. Since the 2011 season, under Ivan Lendl's coaching, Murray has played a more offensive game and has also worked to improve his second serve, forehand, consistency and mental game which have all been crucial to his further success.[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-How_Andy_Murray_turned_a_second_serve_into_a_lethal_weapon-461)[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-463)[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-464)[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-465)

In June 2012, the Swiss watch manufacturer  [Rado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rado_(watch) "Rado (watch)")  announced that Murray had signed a deal to wear their D-Star 200 model.[[477]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-477)

## Charitable work

Murray is a founding member of the  [Malaria No More UK](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaria_No_More_UK "Malaria No More UK")  Leadership Council and helped launch the charity in 2009 with  [David Beckham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Beckham "David Beckham"). Footage from the launch at Wembley Stadium can be seen on YouTube and the charity's website.[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-480)  Murray also made 'Nets Needed', a short public service announcement, for the charity to help raise awareness and funds to help in the fight against malaria.[[481]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-481)  Murray has also taken part in several charity tennis events, including the  [Rally for Relief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open#Rally_for_Relief "2011 Australian Open")  events that took place prior to the start of the  [2011 Australian Open](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Australian_Open "2011 Australian Open").[[482]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-482)

In June 2013, Murray teamed up with former British No. 1 Tim Henman for a charity doubles match against Murray's coach and eight-time grand slam champion Ivan Lendl, and No. 6 Tomáš Berdych at the  [Queen's Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Club "Queen's Club")  in London. The event named  [Rally Against Cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Aegon_Championships#Rally_Against_Cancer "2013 Aegon Championships")  was organised to raise money for Royal Marsden Cancer Charity after his best friend and fellow British player Ross Hutchins was diagnosed with  [Hodgkin's lymphoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hodgkin%27s_lymphoma "Hodgkin's lymphoma").[[483]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-483)[[484]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-484)  The event took place following the final day of competitive play at the  [AEGON Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013_Aegon_Championships "2013 Aegon Championships"), on Sunday 16 June. Subsequently, following his victory at the tournament, Murray donated his entire prize money pot to  [The Royal Marsden Cancer Charity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Royal_Marsden_NHS_Foundation_Trust "The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust").[[485]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-485)

In June 2014, following the death of  [Elena Baltacha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elena_Baltacha "Elena Baltacha")  due to  [liver cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liver_cancer "Liver cancer"), Murray featured in an event known as 'Rally for Bally'. Murray played at Queen's Club alongside Victoria Azarenka,  [Martina Hingis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martina_Hingis "Martina Hingis"), Heather Watson and his brother Jamie. The event raised money for the Royal Marsden Cancer Charity and the Elena Baltacha Academy of Tennis. Children from Baltacha's academy took to the court to play alongside Murray.[[486]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-486)[[487]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-487)  As a result of his various charitable exploits, Murray was awarded the  [Arthur Ashe Humanitarian of the Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Arthur_Ashe_Humanitarian_award "ATP Arthur Ashe Humanitarian award")  award for 2014.[[488]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Murray#cite_note-488)
